text: So before we go into our methods, I'll briefly talk about active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Probably most of you are already familiar with the topic, but I'll just rehearse some of that stuff, even if it's just to get accustomed to our way of notation, let's say, because everybody has his own notation, and at least it will put us all on the same page for the next part.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, it all starts with having an agent that needs to interact with the environment, and the agent is assumed to be kind of separated from the environment from the so-called Markov blanket.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So on the one hand, the agents can perform actions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These actions, these will impact the environment, which is kind of a generative process that has some hidden states that provide you, given your action, it provides you with some sensory observation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in this case, an action could be for the robot to drive around,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and put some currents on the motors and observation could be some pixels from the camera.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then the goal of the agent is to build a generative model where he has his own, he builds his own state space basically, he derives how actions have effect on the states and how these states then would generate these observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the question is, how can we build a generative model that actually comes up automatically with kind of a proper state space to learn this model?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So basically, the generative model then looks like a POMDP, a partially observable Markov decision process.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it just means that we assume that a state at a given time step, it only depends on the previous states and the action that you were doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And each state gives rise to a certain observation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so then we end up with the so-called free energy principle that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: basically what we want to do is we want to build a model that maximizes log evidence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So here you see the formula for the free energy and you can unpack it in several ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the first way is basically by stating that minimizing free energy is actually maximizing the
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: evidence lower bound let's say and if you're at this free energy minimum then basically you have your approximate posterior that this is actually equals to your or very close to your your crew posterior
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But then the third line is basically what we typically use for optimizing our model, which is basically, on the one hand, a complexity term.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You want to have your states explain the way as simple as possible, whereas you want to have the highest accuracy to predict whatever
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in this case, our variational approximate posterior is something that maps observations and actions into inferring your current state.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But what about the future?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in the past, you basically knew which actions you were doing and you saw the observations that came in.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you could kind of infer which states would have given rise to the observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's basically the reality of the past.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But then in the future, things change a bit because now you don't know what you will observe.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And also you have to select the actions you will do.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: so the actions we will basically denote them as being generated by so-called policy but in in this case the policy is basically just yeah what is a certain sequence of actions basically and you now have to create some expectations not only on future states but also on future observations so what
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which states do i think i will visit by doing some actions but also what kind of observations do i think that i will see if i visit these states so then the free energy becomes the so-called expected free energy and again you can unpack this thing
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as follows.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So basically what happens is again you have on the one hand the log probability of your posterior model minus log probability of your
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: of your kind of model and now the difference is that that you don't know yet the observations in the future so yet you condition it on the policy so everything will depend on the actions you will do and you also have to take the expectation over all kinds of of outcomes you expect
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then going to the second line, you basically make the move that if your model is sufficiently trained, then basically your approximate posterior will be very close to the true posterior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this then basically allows you to rewrite the final term.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I see now that I wrote it in a different way, but you can rewrite this either as an information gain on your states and moving towards preferred outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can also rewrite it the way we did here, where you basically state, okay, at some point in the future, I will visit some states.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is this log P of S star given the policy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you basically replace this by some prior belief that regardless which policy I'm actually choosing, I believe that some point in the future I will realize my preferences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's why you lose the conditioning on the policy in the last equation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this then basically becomes a KL divergence that says, okay, I want to find the policies that actually bring me close to the states that I prefer, that I like to be into.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then on the other hand, you have this ambiguity term that says, okay, what I don't like is to visit states that can give me any observation that I cannot predict.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: so that that brings us to the the whole active influence scheme so at each time step you basically evaluate your expected free energy for each of your policies
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you then basically assume that you will choose the policy that will actually minimize your expected free energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you take the softmax over minus g, and you also weigh this with this gamma parameter, which is just like the precision.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if you have a high precision, then basically you will have a very peaked output of the softmax function.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the softmax will basically become a max.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you then definitely
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: choose the policy with lowest expected free energy if you relax the precision a bit then basically you allow for some more randomness in the system and then basically you end up inferring the next action according to what is the next action that I should take according to this policy

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: given your previous states and the action you did in that state second part oh yeah and also the the initial state is basically also part of the transition model but then you just provide with a zero action for example just to bootstrap it the second part is then the likelihood model so given state you want to have a model that that predicts what kind of observation you will you will see
speaker: SPEAKER_00
